misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program computes the distance between two points using x1, y1, x2, y2 rather than reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and mapping it to a letter grade with conditional logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is to read two coordinate points and calculate the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use if/else conditionals to determine whether it falls in the A, B, C, D, or F range and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Prompts the user for "Enter x1 and y1" and "Enter x2 and y2" instead of "Enter grade".
Reads four double values instead of a single numeric grade.
No conditional statements to check grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.).
Outputs a distance value with the message "The distance of the two points is" instead of a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the problem specification or reuse of code from a different exercise involving distance between two points.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the distance-calculation logic with code that reads one numeric grade and uses if/else-if statements to check which range it falls into and print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (inputs, processing, and output) corresponds to a distance calculation task and none of it matches the described grade calculator requirements.

evidence.note: Code clearly implements a distance-between-points calculation with four coordinate inputs and no grade-based conditionals, contradicting the grade calculator specification.

misconceptions.name: Complete Miss of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code calculating the distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator program. Absolutely none of the required functionality (reading a single grade, conditional grading logic, printing a letter grade) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment (distance calculation between two points).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional logic to map it to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Reads four input doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Calculates distance using Math.sqrt
Outputs a numeric distance value, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The wrong program was submitted, demonstrating a fundamental failure to address the core requirements of Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and replace the current distance calculation logic with the correct input reading and conditional statements to determine the letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code is unambiguously implementing the distance formula, a task unrelated to the grade calculation problem.

evidence.note: The variables read (x1, y1, x2, y2) and the calculation (distance formula) directly conflict with the assignment requirements.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: The output is a calculated distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Complete task mismatch - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem. This indicates either misunderstanding of requirements, copy-pasting wrong code, or not reading the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should calculate the Euclidean distance between two coordinate points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code prompts for 'x1 and y1' instead of a grade
Code prompts for 'x2 and y2' instead of comparing against thresholds
Code calculates distance formula instead of grade ranges
No conditional logic for grade boundaries
Output is a distance value, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misalignment between the submitted solution and the problem requirements. Likely causes: wrong file submitted, copy-paste error from a different assignment, or failure to read the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task requires: (1) Read ONE numeric grade, (2) Use if-else statements to check ranges, (3) Output a single letter grade. Start fresh with the correct problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Near certain - the code is solving an entirely different problem (distance calculator vs. grade calculator) with no overlap in logic or I/O requirements.

evidence.note: Entire program solves Euclidean distance problem instead of grade calculator. Prompts are for coordinates, calculation is distance formula, output is a decimal distance value.
No grade input prompts ('Enter grade:') as specified in problem. No conditional logic for grade ranges. Missing the core requirement.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade-to-letter calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that reads two 2D points and computes the distance between them instead of reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and determining the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads coordinates for two points and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then use conditionals to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
All variables represent coordinates and a distance, with no variable for a grade or letter.
Output message reports the distance between two points instead of a letter grade.
No conditional logic or range checks for grade intervals are present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between assignment prompts or reuse of code from a different exercise involving the distance formula.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance-formula logic and redesign the program to (1) read a single numeric grade from input, and (2) use an if-else chain to map the grade into the A/B/C/D/F ranges and print the correct letter.
related_concepts: Reading a single input value from the user
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (input prompts, variable names, computation, and output) matches a distance-formula problem and there is no trace of grades or letter outputs.

evidence.note: Shows the program reading four coordinate values, computing a distance with the distance formula, and printing that distance instead of handling a single grade and mapping it to a letter.

misconceptions.name: Solved wrong problem (Distance Formula instead of Grade Calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points using the Euclidean distance formula, rather than the requested program for calculating a letter grade from a numeric input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have misunderstood the assignment requirements or submitted code intended for a different problem (perhaps a previous one or a test case for distance calculation).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer/double grade input.
Code performs mathematical calculation (distance formula) instead of conditional logic (grade ranges).
Output message is about 'distance' instead of 'Letter grade'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of assignment requirements or incorrect file submission/upload.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully. Create a new program that focuses on reading a single grade input and uses if/else if/else structures to assign letter grades based on the specified numerical ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code is entirely dedicated to solving the distance calculation problem (which involves reading four coordinates and applying the distance formula), confirming it does not address the Grade Calculator requirement at all.

evidence.note: Reads coordinates instead of a single numeric grade.
Performs distance calculation instead of grade logic.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: Outputs distance instead of letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect number and type of variables for the task
misconceptions.description: The student declared and initialized four double variables (x1, y1, x2, y2) corresponding to four inputs, whereas the Grade Calculator task required only a single integer or double variable for the grade input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student is setting up variables for a coordinate geometry problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The Grade Calculator scenario requires one variable to store the grade, ideally an integer or double, depending on expected precision.
symptoms: Use of variables x1, y1, x2, y2 and d.
Reads four inputs.
Variables are doubles, which is excessive if the grade input was required.
misconceptions.root_cause: The variables match the substituted distance calculation problem, showing the underlying issue is problem substitution.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Define a single variable, perhaps named 'grade', to store the input needed for the grading task.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student uses variables specific to coordinate geometry, proving the wrong problem was addressed.

evidence.note: Declaration of four coordinate variables read from input.
